description: Prerequisite(s): LATN 203 or equivalent (such as placement score of 600). Continuous reading of several Latin authors in poetry (e.g., Ovid, Virgil, Horace) as well as some more complex prose, in combination with ongoing review of Latin grammar. By the end of the course students will have thorough familiarity with the grammar, vocabulary, and style and style of the selected authors, will be able to tackle previously unseen unseen passages by them, and will be able to discuss language and and interpretation. Note: Completion of Latin 204 with C- or higher fulfills Penn's Foreign Language Requirement.
name: INTERMED LATIN: POETRY

values.comments:
This course covers the translation and interpretation of Latin poetry. Taught by a graduate student, the course studies grammatical structures and various readings in Latin works.
Students’ thoughts on the course’s pace were divided. While several students liked the regularity of the course, others commented that it was inconsistent, with some weeks requiring a lot of immediate work and others entailing only very little. Some students further explained that because there was a lot of material to cover in the course, the class moved slowly.
According to students, Nethercut related to the students and “understands the existence of life outside the classroom.” Many thought that his grading and homework policies were “very well announced and fair.” Nethercut was found to be “talented, motivated, and charismatic”. It was also pointed out that “grades were secondary with Jason and learning was first.”
Because the grading system was fair, students believed that their grades well represented their work and effort. Some students felt that the classes that preceded this course (such as LATN 101 and LATN 203) covered more in depth material.
